overview.short: Hafnia species are Gram-negative, facultatively anaerobic rods within the Enterobacterales, most commonly encountered as environmental and intestinal flora but occasionally associated with opportunistic infections.
overview.clinical_context: Usually isolated as a commensal or contaminant, but can be recovered from opportunistic infections (e.g., gastroenteritis, urinary tract infections, respiratory specimens) particularly in compromised hosts.

field_notes.Lactose Fermentation: Typically non-lactose fermenting on MacConkey (colourless colonies).
field_notes.Ornithine Decarboxylase: Commonly positive and useful for separating Hafnia from some other Enterobacterales.
field_notes.Citrate: Often variable across strains and not genus-defining alone.

key_differentiators.notes: Non-lactose fermentation helps separate Hafnia from common lactose fermenters.
ODC positivity can support Hafnia in a non-lactose fermenting Enterobacterales context.
K/A with variable gas is consistent with many Hafnia isolates.

common_confusions.reason: Shared Enterobacterales background and overlapping biochemical reactions; Hafnia tends to be non-lactose fermenting.
Both may be non-lactose fermenters with overlapping citrate/MR/VP variability.
Similar colony appearance on MacConkey; differentiation relies on biochemical pattern and (if present) pigment/gelatinase profiles.

when_to_question_identification: Strong lactose fermentation (pink MacConkey colonies) argues against Hafnia and suggests Enterobacter/Klebsiella/Escherichia.
H2S production argues against Hafnia and suggests Salmonella/Citrobacter/Edwardsiella.
Oxidase positivity is inconsistent with Enterobacterales and argues against Hafnia.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Key supportive discriminator among non-lactose fermenting Enterobacterales.
Helpful as part of an Enterobacterales biochemical panel to separate close matches.
Standardized Enterobacterales identification strip; useful for differentiating Hafnia from similar genera.
Reliable genus/species-level identification when biochemical overlap is high.
